title: Between 1 April 2017 and 31 March 2018, will an armed group from the Philippines engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Philippines?
preds: President Duterte's "War on Drugs" seems to be on hold  and focus is now on separatists in the south.  Although forecasting on this question closes in less than a month, it won't be decided till end March 2018, which leaves plenty of time for another campaign.  Consequently, I'm reducing my forecast from 65 to 45% but no further.

Is the ostensible war on drugs in which civilians have been and will be killed by police a different campaign on Luzon than on Mindanao, for example; or because it has been moderated a bit, will it count as a different one when Duterte ratchets it up again? Not sure whether they can rack up a big enough score, but is this a campaign directed at civilians?

Drug war continues. EWP marked it as a mass-killing episode in 2016. More than 7,000 were killed in the last six months of 2016, according to HRW. If killing continues at anything close to that pace from April 2017 forward, the 1,000-death threshold will be passed early in the April 2017-March 2018 window.

Non-state armed groups in the Philippines almost exclusively target state security forces. While civilians also fall victim to such attacks (IEDs, UXO, etc.), there is usually no systematic approach to it. Inter-clan or inter-religious violence is usually on a small scale. State security forces are unlikely to specifically target civilians, in part due to a fragile yet promising peace process with the major Muslim rebel group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). In areas where communist rebels are present, the civilian population is rarely a deliberate target. One reason might be that both the state security forces and civilians in such areas are predominately Christian and share language and culture - at least to a larger degree than in Muslim areas. 
DISCLAIMER: The way the question is asked leaves it open if the "War on Drugs" should be included in the answer or not. When considering the probability of systematic mass killing, I did NOT include the deaths of civilians in the "War on Drugs". However, I can see why one would, so I suggest to rephrase the question or to split it into two separate questions. If you consider the "War on Drugs" to be a campaign that systematically kills civilians in the Philippines, the probability for the killing of 1,000 or more civilians within one year would be closer to 99%.
